text: Superdelegates are party congresspersons, senators and bigwigs in each state who are free to support whom they like.
Ted Cruz's victory raised questions about Donald Trump's status as the Republican front-runner. Marco Rubio's close third greatly bolstered his campaign.
Hillary Clinton won the Democratic caucuses but by the thinnest-ever margin of victory in the party's contests here. Bernie Sanders was ahead among every age group except for the over 65s.
The result was seen as a mess for the Republican establishment, as no mainstream candidate emerged with a strong enough showing to challenge Donald Trump.
Bernie Sanders chalked up a win in this state, which borders his native Vermont, by a much bigger margin than the polls had forecast.
Jeb Bush ended his campaign after coming a poor fourth here. Evangelicals accounted for 72% of voters; a third of them plumped for Donald Trump.
Hillary Clinton's victory boosted her campaign. She won 76% of black voters, who made up 13% of caucus participants. Hispanics accounted for 19%
Donald Trump had a big win here. A third of the caucus-goers were over 65; just 7% were under 30.
The first state in the South to vote. In 2008 blacks made up 55% of the Democratic-primary electorate.
Newt Gingrich won the primary in 2012; only 6% of Republicans here opposed the Tea Party at the time.
In 2012 53% of Republican-primary voters in this New England state said they were moderate or liberal.
The primary is open to all voters, not just Republicans. A third said they were "independent" in 2012.
Republicans here are very conservative; in 2012 80% were evangelical Christians and 32% thought abortion should be always illegal.
The Republican electorate here is fairly moderate; only 15% described themselves as "very conservative" in 2012.
More than 70% of Republican-primary voters in 2012 were evangelical Christians, one of the highest proportions in any state.
Three quarters of Republican-primary voters were Christian evangelicals in 2012, handing victory to Rick Santorum.

allocation notes: if only one candidate receives 20% statewide, delegates are split between that candidate and the runner-up
text: After California, Texas has the most delegates to the Republican national convention.
The state is holding its primary on Super Tuesday; in 2012 it voted much later in the calendar.

allocation notes: 85% threshold awards district delegates as well as statewide ones
text: The activists who turn up to Republican caucuses here are a conservative bunch; in 2012 they plumped for Rick Santorum.
Sarah Palin, a former governor, has endorsed Donald Trump. Mitt Romney eked out a narrow win at the caucuses in 2012.
Republicans will caucus on Super Tuesday, and hold a binding vote to allocate delegates at a state party meeting in the spring.
In 2008, 51% of voters in the Democratic-primary electorate were black, and 63% were female.
The home state of Bernie Sanders.
Hillary Clinton won the Democratic primary in 2008. A third of the voters were from northern Virginia (suburbs of Washington, DC).
Half the voters in the 2008 Democratic primary here were black. Only 16% of all voters said they were "very liberal".
Democratic-primary voters here are highly educated; in 2008 33% held a postgraduate degree. 45% said they were Catholic.
In 2008, a fifth of the state's Democrats said they were conservative. Hillary Clinton won that year's primary.
Hillary Clinton won the Democratic primary here in 2008. 30% of the voters were black.
Democrats are holding just a primary this time; in 2008 they also held a caucus. Hillary Clinton won the primary, Barack Obama the caucus.
Hillary Clinton has a close connection to the state as the wife of a former governor; she won 70% of the vote in 2008.
Barack Obama won the Democratic caucuses here by a wide margin over Hillary Clinton in 2008.
Democrats caucus here on Super Tuesday. In 2008 Hillary Clinton lost heavily to Barack Obama.
American Samoa and other American territories vote in the party primaries, but not in the presidential election.
The Republican caucuses are restricted to party members this year; in 2012 independents were allowed to take part.
Rick Santorum easily won the caucuses in 2012, taking more votes than the other candidates combined.

allocation notes: delegates for candidates who fail to reach 20% are unbound
text: Half the Republicans here in 2012 said they were "very conservative"; 61% were evangelical Christians.
Republicans are holding caucuses in Kentucky. Democrats will conduct a primary in May.
The Democratic caucuses in 2008 were dominated by Barack Obama, who took 74% of the vote.
Democrats here are fairly moderate. In 2008 half the voters in the primary were black.
Hillary Clinton lost heavily here in 2008.
Puerto Rico  and other American territories vote in the party primaries, but not in the presidential election.
Barack Obama won the Democratic caucuses in 2008 with 60% of the vote.
After Utah, Idaho has the highest proportion of Mormons in America (about 25% of the state population).
14% of the voters in the 2012 Republican primary were union members.
83% of Republicans in the 2012 primary were born-again or evangelical Christians, the highest proportion of any state.
Mitt Romney won the caucuses here in 2012.
30% of the Democrats who voted in the 2008 primary were union members, the highest proportion in any state.
50% of the voters in the 2008 Democratic primary were black.
By this date 50% of the Republican delegates will have been allocated.
Guam  and other American territories vote in the party primaries, but not in the presidential election.

This is the last state in the South to vote in the Republican primaries.

This is another big state where the winner of the Republican primary gets all the state's delegates.
This is a big prize in the Republican race; the winner of the primary gets all the state's delgates.

allocation notes: 50% statewide winner takes district delegates as well; districts have 5 delegates each
text: In 2012 Republicans held caucuses that were descibed as chaotic. They're having a primary this time.

This is the second-biggest state to vote in terms of delegates for the Democrats at this stage (after Texas).

The last state in New England to vote in the primaries.

Ties with Vermont for having the fewest delegates at the Republican convention.
Just 2% of the vote in the 2012 Republican primary came from the city of Baltimore.

Once a Democratic stronghold, this is now a Republican state.

The primary is closed to registered Republicans.

California has the most delegates, but the lowest of any state per 100,000 people: 0.44 for the Republicans.
California has the most delegates. A longstanding complaint is that it votes so late in the primary calendar.
